name: Indra
title: Hindu - Indra

children: contrasting with his heroic vedic portrayal
contrasting with his heroic vedic portrayal

description:
Indra stands as one of the most revered and multifaceted figures in Hindu mythology. Revered as the deity of Shakra (Mighty One), Devendra (Lord of Gods), Vajrapani (Wielder of Vajra), Indra embodies the fundamental forces that shape both the divine and mortal realms. 

According to Hindu sacred texts, Indra's origins represent eternal aspects of Brahman, cycling through cosmic ages and divine incarnations The worship of Indra became central to Hindu religious practice, with devotees seeking their favor through puja ceremonies, bhakti devotion, and sacred pilgrimages. 

Sacred symbols associated with Indra include Vajra (thunderbolt weapon), Bow and arrows, Rainbow. These emblems appear throughout Hindu art and literature, serving as powerful reminders of Indra's divine presence and authority. The mythology surrounding Indra reveals deep insights into Hindu worldview, particularly concerning Shakra (Mighty One) and humanity's relationship with the divine. 

The legacy of Indra extends far beyond ancient Hindu civilization. Indra continues to receive active worship by millions of devotees. The deity's philosophy and practices have influenced yoga, meditation, and spiritual movements globally Scholars continue to study Indra's mythology for its profound insights into Hindu culture, religion, and philosophy.

sections.title: Description
sections.content: Also known as ‚ö° Indra. Associated with Shakra (Mighty One), Devendra (Lord of Gods), Vajrapani (Wielder of Vajra). Known by the epithets: Shakra (Mighty One).

sections.title: Family
items: Children: jayanta (warrior son), jayanti (daughter), agni (fire god), vayu (wind god), especially vritra, jealous in later epics, contrasting with his heroic vedic portrayal

cultural_significance: Wields the power of storms and atmospheric phenomena

topic_panels.title: Origins & Mythology
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Origins

Indra's mythology cosmic ocean, Brahman manifestation, trimurti. The deity's role in Hindu cosmology reflects fundamental aspects of how ancient peoples understood divine power and cosmic order.

### Creation Accounts

Primary sources describe Indra's emergence and divine nature through various sacred narratives. These origin stories served both religious and cultural functions, establishing divine authority and cosmic principles.

**Time Period:** c. 1500 BCE - present

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of Indra involved puja, bhakti, pilgrimage, festivals. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Indian subcontinent, temples and shrines dedicated to Indra served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated Indra's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.

topic_panels.title: Symbols & Iconography
topic_panels.content:
### Sacred Symbols

Key symbols associated with Indra:

- **Vajra (thunderbolt weapon)**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **Bow and arrows**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **Rainbow**: Represents divine power and sacred authority
- **Airavata (white multi-tusked elephant)**: Represents divine power and sacred authority

### Divine Attributes

As deity of Shakra (Mighty One), Devendra (Lord of Gods), Vajrapani (Wielder of Vajra), Meghavahana (Rider of Clouds), Thunder, Lightning, Rain, War, Heaven, Kingship, Indra embodies these cosmic principles. The iconography reveals how ancient peoples visualized divine power and cosmic forces.

### Artistic Representations

Ancient artworks depict Indra with distinctive attributes that communicate divine identity and authority to worshippers.

topic_panels.title: Modern Influence
topic_panels.content:
### Cultural Legacy

Yoga, meditation, New Age spirituality. The mythology of Indra continues to resonate in contemporary culture, literature, and spiritual practices.

### Academic Study

Modern scholars analyze Indra's mythology through multiple lenses‚Äîreligious studies, anthropology, archaeology, and comparative mythology‚Äîrevealing insights into ancient worldviews.

### Popular Culture

Indra appears in modern media, from fantasy novels to video games, demonstrating the enduring power of ancient mythology to capture human imagination and address timeless questions.

related_myths.title: The Birth of Indra
related_myths.summary: The sacred account of how Indra came into being, establishing their divine authority and cosmic role in Hindu mythology.

related_myths.title: Indra and the Sacred Quest
related_myths.summary: A legendary tale of Indra's heroic deeds or cosmic achievements that shaped the world and demonstrated divine power.

related_myths.title: Indra and the Divine Council
related_myths.summary: Stories of Indra's interactions with other deities, revealing the complex relationships and hierarchies of the Hindu pantheon.

related_myths.title: Indra and the Gift of Shakra (Mighty One)
related_myths.summary: The mythological account of how Indra became associated with Shakra (Mighty One) and bestowed this gift upon humanity or the cosmos.

related_myths.title: The Legacy of Indra
related_myths.summary: How Indra's actions and teachings continue to influence the world, establishing sacred traditions and cosmic principles.
